title.narrative: Strengthening Media in DRC via Fondation Hirondelle 2017 - 2019

description.narrative:
Svenska ambassaden i Kinshasa kommer via Foundation Hirondelle stötta det kapacitetsbyggande programmet för mediasektorn i Demokratiska Republiken Kongo (DRK). Insatsen har som mål att öka tillgängligheten till tv- och radiosändningar med öppen och fri informationsspridning i provinserna Kinshasa, Nord-Kivu, Sud-Kivu, Kongo Central, Kwango, Kwilu, Mai-Ndombe and Haut-Katanga. Insatsen vill även stötta kapacitetsbyggande aktiviteter för de mediaaktörer som är engagerade i programmet.
Fondation Hirondelles insats sträcker sig över en 24-månadsperiod, med en total budget på USD 1 986 555 motsvarande SEK 17 848 654 och där Sverige finansierar 15 000 000 SEK av den totala budgeten.
Det övergripande för insatsen är öka tillgängligheten till kvalitativ media som gör att framförallt kvinnor och unga kan bli aktivare deltagare i samhällsutvecklingen i DRK. Insatsen omfattar såväl spridande som producering av medialt material samt stöd till utvalda media, framförallt radiokanaler.
Insatsen har tre förväntade övergripande resultat:
1. Ökad kompetens hos partnerorganisationer vad gäller deras journalistiska- och mediala färdigheter, främst vad gäller produktion och sändning av lokala program med olika tema, anpassade till kvinnor och ungdomar.
2. Stärka kompetens hos ledarskapet vid partnerorganisationerna och på så sätt öka organisatoriska kapacitet och hållbarhet.
3. Ökad och mer regelbunden inkomst för mediala partnerorganisationer bland annat genom att öka partners färdigheter inom marknad och management.
Instabilitet och oförutsägbarhet i det politiska och säkerhetsmässiga läget i DRK gör det svårt att förutse sannolikheten att resultatmålen ska kunna uppnås innan avtalsperiodens slut. Beredskap för att justera projektupplägg finns hos Foundation Hirondelle om detta skulle visa sig behövas, t ex om ytterligare restriktioner för media i DRK blir fallet.

The contribution will support Foundation Hirondelle in capacity building for the media sector in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The aim is to increase accessibility to television and radio broadcasts with open and free dissemination of information in the provinces Kinshasa, North Kivu, Sud-Kivu, Congo Central, Kwango, Kwilu, Mai-Ndombe and Haut-Katanga. The initiative will also support capacity-building activities for the media actors involved in the Project, foremost radio channels and some TV channels.
The contribution will extend over 24 month and Fondation Hirondelle is the agreement partner to Sweden. It has a total budget of USD 1 986 555, whereof the Embassy supports with 15 000 000 SEK.
The overall goal of the contribution is to increase accessibility of information by spreading and producting media material. It is young people and women who are the main focus group in the initiative, this to increase their opportunities for active participation in society.

The overall objective of this intervention is to contribute to the consolidation of a democratic society in the DRC through the diversification and improvement of the media offer of general interest, especially for young people and women, during and after the electoral cycle. The specific objective of this invervention is: The Media content is produced and disseminated for the special attention of young people and women in the DRC to give them the information they need for better participation in public life; and The Partner media are strengthened through structuring coordination and actions that enhance journalistic, editorial, managerial, and revenue-generating skills. Revenue generation from institutional communication campaigns broadcast on the Fondation Hirondelle media network partners

description.narrative: Fondation Hirondelle (FH) is the recipient of a grant from SIDA for the period of September 2017 to September 2019, altogether with its network of media partners in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Fondation Hirondelle has been engaged in the mission of providing to young people and women in the DRC the information they need to participate more effectively in public life. This was done under the project Médias Citoyens pour la participation des populations à la Vie Publique (MCVP) which has as main objective: “To contribute to the consolidation of a democratic society in the DRC through the diversification and improvement of the media offer of general interest, especially for young people and women, during and after the electoral cycle”. As highlighted by the external evaluation carried out as part of this grant, the FH has achieved the following in the past two years of this grant: With regard to the first outcome of the project: “Media contents are produced and broadcasted specially to youth and women in DRC, in order to provide them all necessary information for a greater participation in the public life”, the indicators are more than satisfying, with an overall significant amount of people targeted who clearly indicate that the content produced was useful and met their expectation (90% of the persons interviewed during the final assessment), and they want or are likely to be more involved in public life (53% of the participants in the public debates; 95% listeners interviewed during the impact studies). As summarized in the final project evaluation, “the activities selected for this project are likely to contribute to the changes desired, including the democratization of the DRC. And answering the question about the extent to which this will happen, the study of project documentation and the evaluation’s field work has presented a number of important areas where change is beginning to take place, both in relation to the increasing participation by women and youth in and around the election period, and through a budding assertiveness among women in general: “when the woman interviewed can do this, there is no reason for me not to try/aim for the same”. Eight public live debates were organized and FH made a specific point to have them also organized in remote country areas, to make sure the most marginalized and isolated can also take the opportunity to express their views and being informed. As report stated during a debate in Matadi, “Today, I decided to become an observer because I just got the information I didn't have before.” As about audio-visual material produced and broadcasted, FH reached the total of 267 portrays; 264 chronicles; 68 magazines and 10 motion design video in 5 languages, which is 95% of what was planned. Looking at the second outcome: “Media partners are strengthened through structuring coordination and actions that improve journalistic, editorial, managerial and income-generation skills”, a wide range of activities were carried out, towards two main results: the improvement of editorial capacities of the radios, and the improvement of their sustainability. Regarding editorial capacities, FH didn’t deliver a big number of training and workshops as they planned because financial resources where not well executed during the project. However, FH focused on the quality of these trainings, and particularly, on follow up support to trainees. 49 radios have seen their staff trained, and 72% of media partners who received editorial support (training and remote coaching) report that their journalists' skills have been upgraded. Four editorial training session were organized during the project implimentation. Regarding the whole radio partners sustainability, FH focused on technical training, technical remote support through a dedicated hotline, and management training. Four management and marketing training were organized targeting the staff of a total of 43 radios. A close follow up was provided including in the phase of setting up income generating activities. One of the major success is also that these trainings were done with local trainers previously trained by Fondation Hirondelle. These local trainers, being also themselves radio managers, were perfect in terms of embracing the specific challenges that local radios can met in terms of management, and to provide tailored counsel related to the context. 61 media outlets have received technical support, and a close coaching was provided for 28 radio managers. More than these figures, 106 radios were embarked in the whole project, receiving broadcasting fees that helped them to fix daily issues (paying invoices, fixing equipment, etc) and then maintain their radios, and 97 of them received additional royalties provided from campaigns obtained and managed by Fondation Hirondelle from other development partners. In this light, a direct amount of 325 086 USD has been directed to media partners during these project implementation, as broadcasting fees, as royalties from additional contracts obtained by Fondation Hirondelle, or as time involvement of correspondents in the project.
